newsitem.title: USA: PG&E convicted of causing 1994 Calif. fire.
newsitem.headline: PG&E convicted of causing 1994 Calif. fire.

text.p: Pacific Gas & Electric Co, a unit of PG&E Corp, has been convicted of causing a 1994 northern California forest fire by neglecting to trim trees, one of which came in contact with a high-voltage power line to ignite the blaze, court officials said.
A jury in Nevada County Municipal Court also found the utility guilty on all but four of 743 misdemeanor counts as a verdict reached Wednesday was read on Thursday, a court clerk said.
Reading of the counts required most of the court's morning session, she noted.
Sentencing was on the court's afternoon agenda, but could be delayed, the clerk said.
Bill Roake, a spokesman for PG&E, said the utility remains "supremely confident our tree-trimming program is one of the premiere programs in the U.S."
The utility trims about 5,000 trees a day within its northern and central California service territory, he noted.
Given the scale of the efforts, he conceded future accidents cannot be ruled out.
Roake said he believed this was the only time the utility has been charged with tree-trimming failure.
But the Nevada City jury found PG&E guilty of deliberately limiting its tree maintenance program, violating a series of state laws on power line clearance and fire breaks.
